cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

They waste time, are costly to use,
wear out, scratch, etc.

in Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ormus" will leave Suez about April 5
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about April 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said April 9
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said April 22

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about April 11th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Port Said about April 14th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos July 20 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos July 20 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

Sealed. tenders (in duplicate) will be received at this Dockyard up to midday, Friday, Novem- ber 29th, for the purchase and removal ’- with- out restrictions of SIX SECOND CLASS STEEL TORPEDO BOATS, complete with BOILERS and ENGINES, and bnilt by THE |
| YARROW SHIPBUILDING ©0., in 1889.
The Boats may be inspected at the Dockyard on application. being made to the Admiral Superintendent.
Permission will not be given for the Boats to be broken opin the Dockyard. =

The Admiral Superintendent does not bind himself to accept the highest or any tender.

“MONDAY OCTOBER 28, 1907.
REUTER'S AGENOY.

‘“The-contradictions in the news from India this week have been very remarkable,” said the “Manchester Guardian” on Oct. 5, “and it was eee more important than now, when the English people have need to be forming some views about our future policy ‘there, that we should have news that will not subside when we begin to build upon it. .

“What Mr. Keir Hardie really said we know from his own telegram to the “Daily Mail,” from & telegram sent by the Calcutta corres- pondent of the “Tribune,” and. also from ‘telegram published from Reateér’s correspon- dent to-day. He had drawn a parallel between the Bengal Government and that of Russia only in so far as concerned the ubiquity of the
police and the suppression of public meetings ; the parallel’ with Armenia had to do solely

with the violation of Hindu women by Moham- medan rowdies ; and as for colonial government, he had said that that was the ultimate goal, not an immediate object. or right. These ex- . planations may not make Mr. Keir Hardie’s speech discreet, but they acquit him of using wild words and rhetorical exaggeration. “Reuter’s corréspondent eithet did not know the context of Mr. Hardie’s parallels or deli- berately suppressed it, in which case’he was. inflaming English opinion ; and, what is moré, when Mr. Hardie returned to Calcutta he was so careless.or 80 prejudiced that he again ‘neglected to give the context, and represented Mr. Hardie’s explanations as an exultant justification. Nor is this the first time by any means that Reuter’s correspondent has been accused of political misrepresentation ; it is not long since we published a letter from six Caloutta editors pom phainitk ofthe prejudiced character of his news ; but this particular ins- tance, being a personal and simple one, is particularly instructive. It shows that Reuter’s correspondent is aman who sees only two’ colours, black and white,and that his telegrams are, therefore, not to be trusted asa founda- | tion for judgments in politics, whose colours, |i in India, as here, are mostly greys and browns. - “This is a very serious matter indeed, for Reuter’s telegrams are the only materials for opinon on Indian affairs that most people have, and they are thé telegrams mainly read, largely because the Agency has the reputation | of being concerned with the dissemination only of. news, and not of views. When an obijoully tendencious telegram appears iti & strong party organ the reader is on his gttard, and has a | chance of correcting the perspective. The | announcement that a telegram comes through | Reater’s 4 Agency gives no such warning, but lulls suspicion. ~ “The country is, in fact, in danger of having
F its opinions.on ute warped by a slow, steady drip of prejudiced news,,as it was in Sonth
Africa, In South Africa the problem of news
collecting was excessively difficult, for the

whole business was in the hands of a wealthy body of men who were determided. thet there | should be no reconciliation, and the home Government was more or less in sympathy with them. The conditions are surely not so-bad in India, ‘nor is the India Office committed to a policy which would make satisfaction of legiti- mate Indian demands impossible...... | “Reuters Calcutta sBrfeatoodont to-day,” ‘continued the “Manchester Guardian,” in its | issue of Oct. 7, “sends an explanation of his ees messages on Mr. Keir Hardie's . 8 peech last week. He says that thé statements were NA ieoaied absolutely without qualification {in the “Statesman,” and _“‘Bengalee,” andother papers. That, ifttue, might be held to justify | his first telegram, which was given on the authority of the Bengali papers ; on the other | side, it would have been only fair to Mr. Keir | Hardie to have waited for confirmation of these reports before sending a telegram which he | must have known would greatly agitate opinion tin England. . : . This illustrates our point of ' Saturday that Reuter’s cotrespondent showed ‘ himself a good advocate, but a bad reporter. ' He can please himself whether he believe’ Mr. | Hardie or not, but he must also have the good- ness to‘let other people’ have a chance of pleas- ‘ing themselves too ; and his business was to report what Mr. Keir Hardie himself said he | said, especially as he had got Mr. Hardie into trouble by reporting pret other people said he said.”

Le Ministére des Finances a l'honneur de rappéler qu’Anx tetmes de l'art. 9 da déoret da 18 Mare 1884, sur la propriété batie, les propriétaires des immeubles batis situés dans ‘les localités assujetties au dit impdt sont tenus de déclarer par écrié avant le 15: no- vembre toutes nonvelles constructions ‘quiils pourraient avoir éleyées ainsi que toutes additions on c enents apportés dans lears
Propridtés exis antes. Ces déclarations divans étre remises av. Gonvernorat ov & la Mondirieh de laquelle

Spathis’ celebrated Mineral and - - Aerated waters are the very best obtainable. [Advt. }
Men's Fashions for Cairo.
It is said that knickerbockers will not be fashionable among the Amoricans this season,
The Plague Bulletin.
One fresh case of plague is reported from Alexandria, the total number of cases now under treatment being six,
Press Libol Caso.
The Court of Cassation has referred on appeal the cases against “‘Al Mokattam,” “Al Watan,” and “Al Shark” to the Court of Appeal for reconsideration.
Tha Summary Court.
The Suminaty Court, Cairo,. has sentenced Hussein Zeki, to three years’ imprisonment on the charge of obtaining jewels on false pretences from Cairo merchants.
Thomas Cook and Son (Egypt) itd.

The coupon dae November 1 on the 5 per Cont, Ist Mortage Debentures of Thomas Cook and Son Egypt) (Limited) will be paid by the London and Westminster, Bank, Temple Bar Branch; on-and after that date, between -the lours of ten and two.
Tho Cairo Season,

The Cairo correspondent of the “Daily ‘Lelegraph” states that the wedding of Mlle. Bertha de Willebois, tthe daughter of Consul- General for Holland, which will take place~ in ‘November; will undoubtedly start the season early forall the diplomatic and official world will return in time to be present.
Protectien of Children.

A meeting was held at the Gouvernorat on Saturday night under the presidency of Mus- tapha Pasha. Ibady with the object of forming’ a society for the protection of ‘Alexandrian children. The aieeting was largely attended, and, subscriptions being called for, a sum of L.E. 240 was promised from among those present.
Omdurman Trade.

Trade is still rather dull at Omdurman, notwithstanding the arrival of large quantities of goods, It was hoped that as soon as the railway was opett and goods began to arrive, business would improve. But this hope has not heen realized. Either sufficient time has not yet been given to the miarket to recuperate, says the “Sudan ‘Times” or financial matters are still in a straitened condition.
Tour Eiffel.

The management of this popular variety hall scored a certain success in departing from its usual programme on Saturday evening, aud presenting to quite a large and thoronghly appreciative gudience a new and skilful turn im the shape of a quick change artist. His sketeh, ine which he acts all the characters, occupies. the whole of the third part of the programme, preceding which a good selection of new variety turns are given, while retaining some of its old favorites.
Locusts in the Sudan,

Ina letter to ‘the “Sudan Times” Ibrahim Bey Farah Sheikh of the Gaalin-tribes, says that the Sudan was visited by locusts in 1866, the swarms‘ were”so nomerous and destructive that they devonred almost every thing in their way. Even leather articles and furnitare did not ‘escape their depredations, The locusts that ««tppeared there this year, however, were more numerous and would have heen mere destructive had it not been for the prompt and active measures taken by the aiithoritfes to destroy them. He drew.a com- parison between the interest taken. by the Government on this occasion and the lack of jitterest which used to be manifested when the country was visited by similar plagues in the Jays of the old regimes.
Clayton Cas Co.

On Saturday afternoon the first trial trip took place of the new steainer for the Alexan- drian station of the Clayton Gas Company Limited. ‘This steamer, which has jyst arrived from England, was built by John Rennie and Company of Greenwich specially for the Com- pany's peculiar requirements and is to he - efly used for the disinfection of ships in the urbour. The steamer is fitted with a com- “re disinfecting apparatus and is thus able th proceed alongside any boat reiniring its Mr. F. MacKinnon, the managing Director of the Company, was on board the steamer during. ita trial on Saturday and expresso “1 himself as-thoronghiy satisfied with he behavionr of the craft, everything working with the greatest smoothness. The company expect to disinfect. their first steamer noxt week in the presence of the members of the (Juarantine Board. The next plant to arrive Alexandria is now on its way from England. This consists of a large but portable disinfect- ng apparatus, mounted ona steam waggon and is specially constructed for the purification of public buildings, houses, factories, barracks, ete.
EGYPTIAN: DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT LIMITED.

There was a decline on Friday last in the shares of the Egyptian Delta Land and Invest- ment Limited in consequence of a report that the Government hed decided in favour of ‘fourah for the sewage farm. If this were troe the estate of the company at Maadi would greatly depreciate in value. According to information received yesterday at Alexandria from Mr. Henriques, the general manager, the company has been definitely informed that the sewage will not be taken to Tourah.
LORD CROM ER REWARDED.
To-Day’s
THE EMPIRE'S ROLL OF FAME.
“Distinguished Talent and. Indomitable Energy.”

To-day marks one of the most important, as well as one of the most interesting eyents in the history of modern Egypt, when the citizens of London set. their seal upon the life-work of the Empire's great Pro-Consul, the Earl of Cromer, by conferring upon him the greatest honour it is in their power to bestow, and enroling his name amongst the list of royalties, distinguished statesmen, and great warriors who have earned the gratitude of their country by their deeds of goodness, renown, and valour.

This presentation. of this signal and much coveted hononr upon Lord Cromer, which was postponed ‘until ‘td-day owing .to the state of his Lordship’s health, has been, looked forwatd to with great interest both by the Corporation and the people of London.

Our readers will; we.think, be better able to ‘understand and appreciate this great ce- remony if we give afew interesting particulars connected with its history. To begin with, London’s “Roll of Fame,” as all know, dates back from ancient times, but our purpose will be, served if we confine our selection therefrom within the past century or so. The first name. that comes to our notice is that,of his Royal Highness the Prince Regent, afterwards George the Fourth, Then, later in 1840, the much lamented Prince Consort became the recipient of the honour, and in course of time his Royal Highness’s four sons, the Prince.of Wales, now our Gracious King Edward the Seventh, the Duke of Edinburgh, the Duke of Connaught, and the late Duke of Albany took up their freedom by patrimony—that is, on attaining their majority they exercised their right to be énrolled as-the sons of a Freeman; their cousin, the Duke of Cambridgeraleo having done so in 1857. The names which next come to our notice are those of great warriors, Lord Nelson, Captain Thomas Hardy, Vice-Admiral Lord Collingwood, The Duke of Wellington, Lord Napier of Magdala, Lord Wolseley, and Lord Kitchener. Of famous statesmen we find the names of William Pitt, afterwards Earl of Chatbam, and in 1784 that of his son the Rt. Hon, William Pitt, who at the age of 24 had been installed as Premier and Chan- ceellor of the Exchequer, of England, Sir Robert Peel, Richard Cobden,. Canning, Bea- consfield, and Gladstone.Of intrepid travel- lers, David Livingstone, and Sir Francis Me- Clintock, who, after many years ‘of unsuccess- ful search and untold hardship. and adventu- res finally ascertained the fate of Sir John Franklin and his fellow-explorers in the Arctic regions. There follow such famons numes as the Earl of Shaftesbury, Lord Brougham, Jen- ner, Rowland Hill, Lord John Russell; Gene- ral Grant, the Marquis of Dufferin and Ava, Lord Milner, Lord Curzon, ete., ete.

An interesting episode is connected with the, conferment of the honour upon Lord Nelsoti, After the victorious ending of the Battle of the Nile, Admiral Nelson forwarded to the. Lord Mayor of London the sword surrendered by the Commanding French Admiral Blanquet, with a letter in which he said that, having the honour of being a Freeman of the City of Lon- don, he offered the sword to the Lord Mayor, and requested that the City would honour him by accepting it, “‘as a remembrance that Bri- tannia still rules the waves”, adding “which thatshe. may ever do is the prayer of your lordship’s most obedientservant, Horatio Nel- son.” The letter is addressed from “Vangoard”, Mouth of the Nile, August 8th, 1798.

There are four methods by which the Free- dom can be acquired (1) by patrimony ; the sons of Freemen being entitled, on attaining their majority, to be enrolled as a matter of right ; (2) by apprentieeship to a master who is ‘already a aan: (3) by purchase ; and (4) by gift conferrered by the Corporation, hon- oris causa, This latter is only granted in recognition of very distinguished ,public servi- ces. ‘The bestowment of the Freedom is still carried ont according to ancient ceremonial, although this is somewhat modified in the case of ordinary admissions. Six citizens, usually selected from the Chairmen of Com- mittees éf the Corporation, give -their testi- mony to the fitness of the person about to be honoured with the Freedom, stating that he is “a man of good name and fame; that he does not desire the Freedom of this City whereby to defraud the,King or this City of their rights, customs, or advantages, but that he will pay his scot and bear his. lot; and so they all say."

A few facts concerning the Court of Com- mon Council, which has the exclusive right of conferring the honorary’ Freedom of the City may not be inappropriate. The Coun- cil consists of 206 members, and shares with the Court of Aldermen, which numbers 26 members, the responsibility, under the Lord Mayor, of the government of the City of London.

The Court is entrusted with the manage- ment of the finances and estates of the Cor- poration, .glects most of the officials, and controls the police. The City also elects a Sheriff of Middlesex as well as of London, and the Lord Mayor is elected by the Trade Guilds in Common Hall from among the Aldermen who have served as Sheriffs.
The Court of Aldermen is of very ancient origin, the first mention of such a Court being found in‘an ancient chronicle, where the writer —himself an Alderman—says; lp the year
1200 were chosen fiye and twenty of the more
- discreet men of the City, and sworn to take
counsel on behalf of the City, together with the Mayor.”

The City appears to have been governed by the Court of Aldermen before the Common Council was-in existance. The earliest known list of members of this Council is found in the City Archives about the date 1285.

The Guildhall, where this very interesting ceremony takes place to-day, is one of London's most ancient and histotic buildings, It still retains the greater part of the old building which was damaged in the great fire of London in 1666, and was rebuilt by Dance in 1798.
The resolution that the Freedom be conferred upon Lord Cromer was passed at a meeting of the Cort of Common Council held on the 31st of May last, and was in the following terins :—

“Resolved that the Freedom of the City in a snitable gold box be presented to the Hon. Evelyn Baring, Earl of Cromer G.C:B, O.M., K.C.8.L, C.LE., in recognition of the long avd eminent public services he has rendered to bis country, and more especially for the dis- tinguished talent. and indomitable energy he has displayed in the discharge during nearly a quarter of a centary’ of thé important and onerous duties which have devolved upon him os the represntative of the British Goveroment in the ancient and historic land of Egypt”. .

This was moved by Mr; J. W. Domoney, Chief Commoner, and Chairman of the City Lands Committee, who paid a warm tribute to the work carried out by Lord Cromer. He said that the services rendered by Lord Cromer during his twenty-five years’ labours in Egypt were ‘quite outside ordinary circumstances, and deserved the greatest recoguition that could be béstowed. It was twenty-five years since Sir
Evelyn Baring went to Egypt. On his arrival
he found.the place in a great «state of chaos, when he left it its administration and poliey—
owing to his wise’ and admirable work—were secure and lasting. His straightforward dealing and impartiality in. all his relations with the natives accounted for his cnormovs influence
over them. Sir George Faudel-Phillips, in seconding the
resolution, said Lord Cromer would go down

to history as one of our great pro-consuls, ranking with such men as Lord Clive. He was not born to greatness, but he was aman who, having great opportunities, made great epochs in our national history. There was nothing which could redound to the interest of. this great Empire and add more to its reputation and glory than whathad been done in Egypt. Instead of that country being, as it now is, amongst the most civilised parts of the- globe, it was not too much to say that it would be in the hands of ignorant and despotic rulers, with the result that the trouble to Europe would be irreparable. Lord Cromer had won the con- fidence of men whose only previous’ expe-
‘riences @f government were a tradition, and

knowledge of. cruelty and. oppression which terrified them—he had first won their confi- denee and then their goodwill. They werd} voting that day to one of their greatest liv: ing statesmen the greatest honour they pos- sessed, and the Corporation, in so doing, was honouring a man who had done wonder- fal'service—a service which had been recognis- ed not only by the people of this country, but by the civilised nations of the world:

The notion was then put and carried una- nimously and with acclamation, and it was referred to the City Lands Committee to make the necessary arrangements in the event of Lord Cromer’s accepting the proposed Phe Rt

he Rt. Hon. Sir Joseph Dimsdale, Bt:, K. 0. V. 0., whose duty it will be to present a Freedom to Lord Cromer to-day, ‘has been Chamberlain of the City of-London since 1902. Hehas served the City faithfully for | many years and had the great .honour of hold- ing the position. of Lord Mayor during the Corgnation year.
KAMEL'S PARTY.

We have received a circular from Mustapha Pasha Kamel asking us if we would like to be members of his own National Party in accord ance with the programme, the ten points of which we published last Friday. His method of forming the party is original and resourceful. | Every one who likes to send him a line saying | that he agrées with bis programme becomes a | non-active member, The active members appat- ently will be his brothers, brothers-inlaw, uncles,consins and other more remote relations, of whom, in Egypt, there-are no limits, and his staff, printers and printers devils.
ANGLO- BGYPTIAN ARTIST.

Mr. A. OQ. lasapiough, the noted Anglo- 3gyptian watercolour artist whose exhibition at 61 New Bond Street; London, W., was recently visited by Princess Henry of Batten. burg, when -her Royal Highness purchased several of Mr. Lawplough’s paintings of Egypt and Nubia, visited Buckingham Palace Jast Friday by special command of King Edward, who expressed his desire to view several of Mr. Lamplough’s pictures. Mr. Lamplough who will arrive in Egypt shortly for the season will exhibit his paintings in Alexandria towards the middle of December.
“OUR DIRECTOR’.
sie KAMEL’S PATRIOTISM.
(From a CorRESPO N DENT)
There is something superb in the spectacle
of a dying soldier who, while knowing that his:
last hope is dead still faces his foe with
unmoved calm, quietly and persistently parry- |
ing such attacks as he is able, until at last the | fatal thrust reachés him, and he falls a martyr to his country, leaving a name to be honoured
‘even by the opposing. forces which took his] j

life. But let us imagine that daring the mom- ents of his last stand, he had filled the with the sound of vain- -glorious. boasting, with a ceaseless song of self praise “behold me I diea martyr to the country which ‘I love so well, through all the ages shall my name be] cherished as that of the noblest martyr, the most wonderful patriot ‘that the world has ever known”: such a man would still merit ‘the praise of his country inasmuch as he: had died in her service though -it is possible that such praise would be not unmixed with contempt. Let us sup that a man whom the world had long since ceased to take seriously, whose power, iff he was really ever possessed with any, had de

ed, let us picture him as striving for the adu ation of the people.He rises upand with feve expressions | of patriotism and zeal proclai himself the chosen leader of his country, pie- tures in viyid langoagethe terrors of a vile and awful opposition (which exists only in his own imagination) exhorting the people to beware, to guard themselves from the terrible conspiracies which are encompassing them on every hand, and to tarn to himas the only being on earth which power endowed to save them. The spec- tacle ceases to be superb, even the contempt ig lacking now, and one is filled only with a sense of pity for.a mistaken brother who is making himself supremely ridiculous.
- But this is all by the way. I had intended writing of the great speech, made by our great “ Director” on the twenty-second day. -of October, i in the year of our Lord one thousand
nine hundred and seven. ““Qur Director” was great, there can be no
doubt as to that, and from the tangled mass of:

controversy which fell from. his august lips I gather the knowledge that; half blinded by the spirit of true patriotism though he -may be, his vision is still sufficiently clear to enable him to see and appreciate his own greatness, equally with the lesser mortals who look up to him with veneration from the street. Some have even gone as far as to suggest that he is of more importance in his own eyes than he is in the eyes of others, but this is no isolated instance of where the ignorance of the common
herd has robbed genius of immediate re-
cognition. The details of his speech are by this time

familiar to all. Every one who could read, rich and poor, lowly and great, expended his half piastre and secured, through the medium of the press, the priceless utterances of a great man. Indeed it is safe to assert that such was thestir causedby the great event, that even Panch” in the brightest days ofits zenith, was never read with more avidity than was the great organ of ‘the National movement yesterday. “Garlands of flowers” we read, were presented to the great man at the conclusion of his wonderful eff rt. Even Gladstone in all his glory never a to this, but here is an orator who has ascend with one bound to tho giddy heights of fam hitherto sacred to an Edna May or Phyllis Dar

It is a pleasant suggestion truly that halfa life mis.spent entitles aman to perfecthappiness for the remainder of his days, and this at least is the inference I draw from the remarks anent ‘the centuries which “our Director” accuses the Egyptians of havingwasted. He asserts that by reason of these mis-spent centuries Egypt is now entitled to immediate and prolonged happiness. May the happiness be both im- mediate and prolonged, Director, but forgive me if I cannot quite follow your argument.
It is certainly most annoying when one has spent both time and money (no matter whose) in the making of a party which is destined’ in
the minds of its promoters to become the re- |.

cognized mouth-piece of those people, who should by every tenet of right considér them- selves oppressed ; it is more than annoying, it is heart-rending, -to find the chosen legion of the oppressed refusing point, blank to act in the roll allotted to them, and’ accusing the month-piece of uttering false echos ; therefore one is not surprised to find that the “Director” should wax indignant, and reiterate his appeal that there should be but one party—his own—
and but one leader —himself. And why should the fortune hunting English
leave their own country in order’ to introduce
reform into the irrigation service of this, when-
they are themselves to benefit’ by it? ‘The re- forms are.of advantage to the Bgyptian also,
[but that is not the point. The. system was

introduced by the English, and is therefore but a part of the time-worn scheme-carefally woven wherein to ensnare the unsuspecting Egyptian, and doubtless the more dangerous by reason of the joanner, in which the venom
of pu is concealed from view. } will not deal at present with the other
numerous points which we scored at Alexandria on the 22nd., but will in conclusion re-echo from the bottom: of my heart the shouts a shook the rafters on that historio
Long live Egypt, Long live patrioti tng live Mustapha Pasha Kamel, —the most amos-
ing man in ae

they would consider themselves discharged. On receipt of this telegram the Ministry cabled to England to the principal of the col-

selves’ as unwartantable impertinence, cabled after due consideration, to the effect that the boys were discharged, and they are now nego- tiating for the filling of their places by two fresh students who, it is to be hoped, will be im- bued with a little more respect for the Minis- try which has taken their welfare in its charge, than their predecessors. ‘

Some persons.take a very long time to ar- rive at the age of discretion, and it would appear that these two youths are particularly backward in this respect. Had they lodged a legitimate complaint as to their treatment or whatever was troubling them, they. woald have been sare of a prompt and thorough enquiry, but they have acted like children, and

THE LATE DR GARNER.
A VALUED STATE SERVANT.

The sudden‘death of Dr. Garner, which we announced on Saturday, came asa yery painful shock to his many friends in Egypt, many of whom had not even known that he was unwell, his illness only dating from ‘Tuesday ‘evening last. Coming to Egypt in 1899, when he joined the Sanitary Department, Tr. Garner was subsequently recommended by his Department to the British Government for service with a survey party in the neighbourhood of Lake Rudolph, to which district, accompanied b
Major Bright D.8.0., of the Rifle Brigade, ca

Major Austin, R.E., he was eventually sent. The whole party was ultimately, attacked by a |i severe form of scurvey, and it was mainly due to the pluck, skill, and endurance displayed by Dr. Garner that the expedition did not end fatally.

Since his return*to Egypt he has been actively engaged in the asaal work of his} department in the provinces, - and was: for the | last two years specially engaged in fightin the plague in Upper Egypt, and it wailki indefatigable work in’ this direction that we |
fear led to the undermining ot his constitution in the first place,
Much of Dr. Garner's work had centred round Tantab and Zagazig. He was well-known throughout Egypt, and it may be truly said
that he did not possess a single enemy in the }.
country, while his death at the early age of forty-one, will be lamented by all who came in contact with the charm.of his personality.
SAFT BL MELOUK ACCIDENT.
EXPLANATIONS OF DELAY.

The official report on the accident ‘which ocourred on the Cairo-Alexandria line on Fri- day last, and which occasioned such prolonged delay; are not yet to be seen, and it is there- fore difficult to ascertain if the delay of four hourswas justified by cirqumstances. It ap-
pears that there were two accidents of a differ-

ent nature at or near the same spot daring the one day. Our Cairo correspondent now writes that, as already reported, the first of these was occasioried by the night mail from Cairo being derailed by a bale of cotton which had fallen from’ an eatlior train, and thereby blocked both up and down lines. ‘A. reliet train was sent for, but it was not until 7°30 a.m., wher the lines were just cleared, that this train arrived, too late to be of any assistance, and the ordin- ary train proceeded to Alexandria,

The aceident occurred at 8.14 a.m. and ata point on the road which is almost at the maxi- mum distance from’ *% breakdown station. It would therefore scem that, provitled that the necessary celerity was used in the despatching of telegrams etc. for the rélief and taking into consideration the diffioulties of time and place: the delay was not inordinate.

The second ‘accident, caused by six trucks of cotton becoming ignited on the track, oceurred at 12,85 p.m. and was responsible for the se- cond delay in the traffic, as it was not ‘consi- dered safe to ron a train past the flaning waggons, even though the track was clear.

AN ABSCONDER ARRESTED.
The Sudan is cukataly an unfavourable place for wonld-be absconders. No one can escape beyond its borders without being cau; up with on the way, as soon as he is “missed.”
